title: Tesla Disbands Dojo Supercomputer Team
description: In a blow to Tesla’s efforts in artificial intelligence, the company has decided to disband its Dojo supercomputer team. Bloomberg’s Max Chafkin discusses what’s behind the move and how the company will pivot with Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

summary: Tesla has disceased its own hardware team in the AI chip space, Dojo Supercomputer Team, and announced it will instead rely on Nvidia chips for training its A.I. models. This move is seen as a setback that many predicted would occur in 2024. However, Max argues that it may be more concerning as Tesla is losing talent due to the ongoing battle for the top in the A.In.I talent war. The company's stock has been stagnant for several years and its valuation estimates range from $500 billion to $100 billion. Max concludes that Tesla's decision to abandon its vertically integrated strategy for the future of supercomputing being vertically integrated could be a setback.
shortSummary: Tesla's decision to stop making its own hardware for training AI models is a setback as it faces competition from other companies seeking talent and market dominance.
argos_summary: Tesla's shift away from developing its own AI chips marks a significant setback for the company, which has historically aimed for vertical integration in manufacturing. CEO Elon Musk indicated during an earnings call that Tesla would rely on both its Dojo system and Nvidia chips for AI model training, reflecting challenges in retaining talent amid a competitive AI landscape. While this change may not be devastating, it raises questions about Tesla's future ambitions and market valuations, especially as other companies aggressively pursue AI development.
